trans-unit.source: Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager
trans-unit.target: Using Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager

trans-unit.source: Use Azure PowerShell to deploy multiple resources as a resource group to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Use Azure PowerShell to deploy multiple resources as a resource group to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager introduces an entirely new way of thinking about your Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager introduces an entirely new way of thinking about your Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: Instead of creating and managing individual resources, you begin by imagining a complex service, such as a blog, a photo gallery, a SharePoint portal, or a wiki.
trans-unit.target: Instead of creating and managing individual resources, you begin by imagining a complex service, such as a blog, a photo gallery, a SharePoint portal, or a wiki.

trans-unit.source: You use a template -- a resource model of the service -- to create a resource group with the resources that you need to support the service.
trans-unit.target: You use a template -- a resource model of the service -- to create a resource group with the resources that you need to support the service.

trans-unit.source: Then, you can manage and deploy that resource group as a logical unit.
trans-unit.target: Then, you can manage and deploy that resource group as a logical unit.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you learn how to use Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager for Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you learn how to use Azure PowerShell with Azure Resource Manager for Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: It walks you through the process of creating and deploying a resource group for an Azure-hosted web app with a SQL database, complete with all of the resources that you need to support it.
trans-unit.target: It walks you through the process of creating and deploying a resource group for an Azure-hosted web app with a SQL database, complete with all of the resources that you need to support it.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you must have Azure PowerShell version 0.8.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you must have Azure PowerShell version 0.8.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: To install the latest version and associate it with your Azure subscription, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To install the latest version and associate it with your Azure subscription, see <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is designed for PowerShell beginners, but it assumes that you understand the basic concepts, such as modules, cmdlets, and sessions.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is designed for PowerShell beginners, but it assumes that you understand the basic concepts, such as modules, cmdlets, and sessions.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Windows PowerShell, see <linkText>Getting Started with Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Windows PowerShell, see <linkText>Getting Started with Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To get detailed help for any cmdlet that you see in this tutorial, use the Get-Help cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To get detailed help for any cmdlet that you see in this tutorial, use the Get-Help cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For example, to get help for the Add-AzureAccount cmdlet, type:
trans-unit.target: For example, to get help for the Add-AzureAccount cmdlet, type:

trans-unit.source: Beginning in version 0.8.0, the Azure PowerShell installation includes more than one PowerShell module.
trans-unit.target: Beginning in version 0.8.0, the Azure PowerShell installation includes more than one PowerShell module.

trans-unit.source: You must explicitly decide whether to use the commands that are available in the Azure module or the Azure Resource Manager module.
trans-unit.target: You must explicitly decide whether to use the commands that are available in the Azure module or the Azure Resource Manager module.

trans-unit.source: To make it easy to switch between them, we have added a new cmdlet, Switch-AzureMode, to the Azure Profile module.
trans-unit.target: To make it easy to switch between them, we have added a new cmdlet, Switch-AzureMode, to the Azure Profile module.

trans-unit.source: When you use Azure PowerShell, the cmdlets in the Azure module are imported by default.
trans-unit.target: When you use Azure PowerShell, the cmdlets in the Azure module are imported by default.

trans-unit.source: To switch to the Azure Resource Manager module, use the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To switch to the Azure Resource Manager module, use the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: It removes the Azure module from your session and imports the Azure Resource Manager and Azure Profile modules.
trans-unit.target: It removes the Azure module from your session and imports the Azure Resource Manager and Azure Profile modules.

trans-unit.source: To switch to the AzureResoureManager module, type:
trans-unit.target: To switch to the AzureResoureManager module, type:

trans-unit.source: To switch back to the Azure module, type:
trans-unit.target: To switch back to the Azure module, type:

trans-unit.source: By default, Switch-AzureMode affects only the current session.
trans-unit.target: By default, Switch-AzureMode affects only the current session.

trans-unit.source: To make the switch effective in all PowerShell sessions, use the Global parameter of Switch-AzureMode.
trans-unit.target: To make the switch effective in all PowerShell sessions, use the Global parameter of Switch-AzureMode.

trans-unit.source: For help with the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet, type: Get-Help Switch-AzureMode or see Switch-AzureMode.
trans-unit.target: For help with the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet, type: Get-Help Switch-AzureMode or see Switch-AzureMode.

trans-unit.source: To get a list of cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module with a help synopsis, type:
trans-unit.target: To get a list of cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module with a help synopsis, type:

trans-unit.source: The output will look similar to the following excerpt:
trans-unit.target: The output will look similar to the following excerpt:

trans-unit.source: To get full help for a cmdlet, type a command with the format:
trans-unit.target: To get full help for a cmdlet, type a command with the format:

trans-unit.source: For example,
trans-unit.target: For example,

trans-unit.source: For the full set of Azure Resource Manager commands, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Cmdlets</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For the full set of Azure Resource Manager commands, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Cmdlets</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This section of the tutorial guides you through the process of creating and deploying a resource group for a web app with a SQL database.
trans-unit.target: This section of the tutorial guides you through the process of creating and deploying a resource group for a web app with a SQL database.

trans-unit.source: You don't need to be an expert in Azure, SQL, web apps, or resource management to do this task.
trans-unit.target: You don't need to be an expert in Azure, SQL, web apps, or resource management to do this task.

trans-unit.source: The templates provide a model of the resource group with all of the resources that you're likely to need.
trans-unit.target: The templates provide a model of the resource group with all of the resources that you're likely to need.

trans-unit.source: And because we're using Windows PowerShell to automate the tasks, you can use these process as a model for scripting large-scale tasks.
trans-unit.target: And because we're using Windows PowerShell to automate the tasks, you can use these process as a model for scripting large-scale tasks.

trans-unit.source: Start PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Start PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: You can use any host program that you like, such as the Azure PowerShell console or Windows PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: You can use any host program that you like, such as the Azure PowerShell console or Windows PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: Use the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet to import the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager and AzureProfile modules.
trans-unit.target: Use the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet to import the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager and AzureProfile modules.

trans-unit.source: To add your Azure account to the Windows PowerShell session, use the Add-AzureAccount cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To add your Azure account to the Windows PowerShell session, use the Add-AzureAccount cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet prompts you for the login credentials for your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet prompts you for the login credentials for your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: After logging in, it downloads your account settings so they are available to Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: After logging in, it downloads your account settings so they are available to Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: The account settings expire, so you need to refresh them occasionally.
trans-unit.target: The account settings expire, so you need to refresh them occasionally.

trans-unit.source: To refresh the account settings, run Add-AzureAccount again.
trans-unit.target: To refresh the account settings, run Add-AzureAccount again.

trans-unit.source: The AzureResourceManager module requires Add-AzureAccount.
trans-unit.target: The AzureResourceManager module requires Add-AzureAccount.

trans-unit.source: A Publish Settings file is not sufficient.
trans-unit.target: A Publish Settings file is not sufficient.

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to create a resource group and its resources, but the easiest way is to use a resource group template.
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to create a resource group and its resources, but the easiest way is to use a resource group template.

trans-unit.source: A resource group template is JSON string that defines the resources in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: A resource group template is JSON string that defines the resources in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: The string includes placeholders called "parameters" for user-defined values, like names and sizes.
trans-unit.target: The string includes placeholders called "parameters" for user-defined values, like names and sizes.

trans-unit.source: Azure hosts a gallery of resource group templates and you can create your own templates, either from scratch or by editing a gallery template.
trans-unit.target: Azure hosts a gallery of resource group templates and you can create your own templates, either from scratch or by editing a gallery template.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, we'll use a gallery template.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, we'll use a gallery template.

trans-unit.source: To see all of the templates in the Azure resource group template gallery, use the Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlet; however, this command returns a large number of templates.
trans-unit.target: To see all of the templates in the Azure resource group template gallery, use the Get-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlet; however, this command returns a large number of templates.

trans-unit.source: To see a more manageable number of templates, specify a publisher parameter.
trans-unit.target: To see a more manageable number of templates, specify a publisher parameter.

trans-unit.source: At the Powershell prompt, type:
trans-unit.target: At the Powershell prompt, type:

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet returns a list of gallery templates with Microsoft as the publisher.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet returns a list of gallery templates with Microsoft as the publisher.

trans-unit.source: You use the Identity property to identify the template in the commands.
trans-unit.target: You use the Identity property to identify the template in the commands.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft.WebSiteSQLDatabase.0.2.6-preview template looks interesting.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft.WebSiteSQLDatabase.0.2.6-preview template looks interesting.

trans-unit.source: When you run the command, the version of the template may be slightly different because a new version has been released.
trans-unit.target: When you run the command, the version of the template may be slightly different because a new version has been released.

trans-unit.source: Use the latest version of the template.
trans-unit.target: Use the latest version of the template.

trans-unit.source: To get more information about a gallery template, use the Identity parameter.
trans-unit.target: To get more information about a gallery template, use the Identity parameter.

trans-unit.source: The value of the Identity parameter is Identity of the template.
trans-unit.target: The value of the Identity parameter is Identity of the template.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet returns an object with much more information about the template, including a summary and description.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet returns an object with much more information about the template, including a summary and description.

trans-unit.source: This template looks like it will meet our needs.
trans-unit.target: This template looks like it will meet our needs.

trans-unit.source: Let's save it to disk and look at it more closely.
trans-unit.target: Let's save it to disk and look at it more closely.

trans-unit.source: Let's save the template to a JSON file on disk.
trans-unit.target: Let's save the template to a JSON file on disk.

trans-unit.source: This step is not required, but it makes it easier to view the template.
trans-unit.target: This step is not required, but it makes it easier to view the template.

trans-unit.source: To save the template, use the Save-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To save the template, use the Save-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Use its Identity parameter to specify the template and the Path parameter to specify a path on disk.
trans-unit.target: Use its Identity parameter to specify the template and the Path parameter to specify a path on disk.

trans-unit.source: Save-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate saves the template and returns the path a file name of the JSON template file.
trans-unit.target: Save-AzureResourceGroupGalleryTemplate saves the template and returns the path a file name of the JSON template file.

trans-unit.source: You can view the template file in a text editor, such as Notepad.
trans-unit.target: You can view the template file in a text editor, such as Notepad.

trans-unit.source: Each template has a parameters section and a resources section.
trans-unit.target: Each template has a parameters section and a resources section.

trans-unit.source: The parameters section of the template is a collection of the parameters that are defined in all of the resources.
trans-unit.target: The parameters section of the template is a collection of the parameters that are defined in all of the resources.

trans-unit.source: It includes property values you can provide when setting up your resource group.
trans-unit.target: It includes property values you can provide when setting up your resource group.

trans-unit.source: Some parameters have a default value.
trans-unit.target: Some parameters have a default value.

trans-unit.source: When you use the template, you are not required to supply values for these parameters.
trans-unit.target: When you use the template, you are not required to supply values for these parameters.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify a value, the default value is used.
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify a value, the default value is used.

trans-unit.source: When parameters have enumerated values, the valid values are listed with the parameter.
trans-unit.target: When parameters have enumerated values, the valid values are listed with the parameter.

trans-unit.source: For example, the sku parameter can take values of Free, Shared, Basic, or Standard.
trans-unit.target: For example, the sku parameter can take values of Free, Shared, Basic, or Standard.

trans-unit.source: If you don't specify a value for the sku parameter, it uses the default value, Free.
trans-unit.target: If you don't specify a value for the sku parameter, it uses the default value, Free.

trans-unit.source: Note that the administratorLoginPassword parameter uses a secure string, not plain text.
trans-unit.target: Note that the administratorLoginPassword parameter uses a secure string, not plain text.

trans-unit.source: When you provide a value for a secure string, the value is obscured.
trans-unit.target: When you provide a value for a secure string, the value is obscured.

trans-unit.source: The resources section of the template lists the resources that the template creates.
trans-unit.target: The resources section of the template lists the resources that the template creates.

trans-unit.source: This template creates a SQL database server and SQL database, a server farm and website, and several management settings.
trans-unit.target: This template creates a SQL database server and SQL database, a server farm and website, and several management settings.

trans-unit.source: The definition of each resource includes its properties, such as name, type and location, and parameters for user-defined values.
trans-unit.target: The definition of each resource includes its properties, such as name, type and location, and parameters for user-defined values.

trans-unit.source: For example, this section of the template defines the SQL database.
trans-unit.target: For example, this section of the template defines the SQL database.

trans-unit.source: It includes parameters for the database name ([parameters('databaseName')]), the database server location [parameters('serverLocation')], and the collation property [parameters('collation')].
trans-unit.target: It includes parameters for the database name ([parameters('databaseName')]), the database server location [parameters('serverLocation')], and the collation property [parameters('collation')].

trans-unit.source: We're almost ready to use the template, but before we do, we need to find locations for each of the resources.
trans-unit.target: We're almost ready to use the template, but before we do, we need to find locations for each of the resources.

trans-unit.source: Most templates ask you to specify a location for each of the resources in a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Most templates ask you to specify a location for each of the resources in a resource group.

trans-unit.source: Every resource is located in an Azure data center, but not every Azure data center supports every resource type.
trans-unit.target: Every resource is located in an Azure data center, but not every Azure data center supports every resource type.

trans-unit.source: Select any location that supports the resource type.
trans-unit.target: Select any location that supports the resource type.

trans-unit.source: You do not have to create all of the resources in a resource group in the same location; however, whenever possible, you will want to create resources in the same location to optimize performance.
trans-unit.target: You do not have to create all of the resources in a resource group in the same location; however, whenever possible, you will want to create resources in the same location to optimize performance.

trans-unit.source: In particular, you will want to make sure that your database is in the same location as the app accessing it.
trans-unit.target: In particular, you will want to make sure that your database is in the same location as the app accessing it.

trans-unit.source: To get the locations that support each resource type, use the Get-AzureLocation cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To get the locations that support each resource type, use the Get-AzureLocation cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: To limit your output to a specific type of of resource, such as ResourceGroup, use:
trans-unit.target: To limit your output to a specific type of of resource, such as ResourceGroup, use:

trans-unit.source: The output will look similar to:
trans-unit.target: The output will look similar to:

trans-unit.source: Now, we have the information that we need to create the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Now, we have the information that we need to create the resource group.

trans-unit.source: In this step, we'll use the resource group template to create the resource group.
trans-unit.target: In this step, we'll use the resource group template to create the resource group.

trans-unit.source: For reference, open the NewWebSiteAnd_Database.json file on disk and follow along.
trans-unit.target: For reference, open the NewWebSiteAnd_Database.json file on disk and follow along.

trans-unit.source: The template file can be very helpful for determining parameter values to pass, such as the correct ApiVersion for a resource.
trans-unit.target: The template file can be very helpful for determining parameter values to pass, such as the correct ApiVersion for a resource.

trans-unit.source: To create a resource group, use the New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To create a resource group, use the New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The command uses the Name parameter to specify a name for the resource group and the Location parameter to specify its location.
trans-unit.target: The command uses the Name parameter to specify a name for the resource group and the Location parameter to specify its location.

trans-unit.source: Use the output of Get-AzureLocation to select a location for the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Use the output of Get-AzureLocation to select a location for the resource group.

trans-unit.source: It uses the GalleryTemplateIdentity parameter to specify the gallery template.
trans-unit.target: It uses the GalleryTemplateIdentity parameter to specify the gallery template.

trans-unit.source: As soon as you type the template name, New-AzureResourceGroup fetches the template, parses it, and adds the template parameters to the command dynamically.
trans-unit.target: As soon as you type the template name, New-AzureResourceGroup fetches the template, parses it, and adds the template parameters to the command dynamically.

trans-unit.source: This makes it very easy to specify the template parameter values.
trans-unit.target: This makes it very easy to specify the template parameter values.

trans-unit.source: And, if you forget a required parameter value, Windows PowerShell prompts you for the value.
trans-unit.target: And, if you forget a required parameter value, Windows PowerShell prompts you for the value.

trans-unit.source: Dynamic Template Parameters
trans-unit.target: Dynamic Template Parameters

trans-unit.source: To get the parameters, type a minus sign (-) to indicate a parameter name and then press the TAB key.
trans-unit.target: To get the parameters, type a minus sign (-) to indicate a parameter name and then press the TAB key.

trans-unit.source: Or, type the first few letters of a parameter name, such as siteName and then press the TAB key.
trans-unit.target: Or, type the first few letters of a parameter name, such as siteName and then press the TAB key.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell completes the parameter name.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell completes the parameter name.

trans-unit.source: To cycle through the parameter names, press TAB repeatedly.
trans-unit.target: To cycle through the parameter names, press TAB repeatedly.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the website and repeat the TAB process for each of the parameters.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the website and repeat the TAB process for each of the parameters.

trans-unit.source: The parameters with a default value are optional.
trans-unit.target: The parameters with a default value are optional.

trans-unit.source: To accept the default value, omit the parameter from the command.
trans-unit.target: To accept the default value, omit the parameter from the command.

trans-unit.source: When a template parameter has enumerated values, such as the sku parameter in this template, to cycle through the parameter values, press the TAB key.
trans-unit.target: When a template parameter has enumerated values, such as the sku parameter in this template, to cycle through the parameter values, press the TAB key.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of a New-AzureResourceGroup command that specifies only the required template parameters and the Verbose common parameter.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of a New-AzureResourceGroup command that specifies only the required template parameters and the Verbose common parameter.

trans-unit.source: Note that the administratorLoginPassword is omitted.
trans-unit.target: Note that the administratorLoginPassword is omitted.

trans-unit.source: When you enter the command, you are prompted for the missing mandatory parameter, administratorLoginPassword.
trans-unit.target: When you enter the command, you are prompted for the missing mandatory parameter, administratorLoginPassword.

trans-unit.source: And, when you type the password, the secure string value is obscured.
trans-unit.target: And, when you type the password, the secure string value is obscured.

trans-unit.source: This strategy eliminates the risk of providing a password in plain text.
trans-unit.target: This strategy eliminates the risk of providing a password in plain text.

trans-unit.source: New-AzureResourceGroup returns the resource group that it created and deployed.
trans-unit.target: New-AzureResourceGroup returns the resource group that it created and deployed.

trans-unit.source: In just a few steps, we created and deployed the resources required for a complex website.
trans-unit.target: In just a few steps, we created and deployed the resources required for a complex website.

trans-unit.source: The gallery template provided almost all of the information that we needed to do this task.
trans-unit.target: The gallery template provided almost all of the information that we needed to do this task.

trans-unit.source: And, the task is easily automated.
trans-unit.target: And, the task is easily automated.

trans-unit.source: After creating a resource group, you can use the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module to manage your resource groups.
trans-unit.target: After creating a resource group, you can use the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module to manage your resource groups.

trans-unit.source: To get all of the resource groups in your subscription, use the Get-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To get all of the resource groups in your subscription, use the Get-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: To get the resources in the resource group, use the Get-AzureResource cmdlet and its ResourceGroupName parameter.
trans-unit.target: To get the resources in the resource group, use the Get-AzureResource cmdlet and its ResourceGroupName parameter.

trans-unit.source: Without parameters, Get-AzureResource gets all resources in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Without parameters, Get-AzureResource gets all resources in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: To add a resource to the resource group, use the New-AzureResource cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To add a resource to the resource group, use the New-AzureResource cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This command adds a new website to the TestRG resource group.
trans-unit.target: This command adds a new website to the TestRG resource group.

trans-unit.source: This command is a bit more complex, because it does not use a template.
trans-unit.target: This command is a bit more complex, because it does not use a template.

trans-unit.source: To add a new template-based deployment to the resource group, use the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command.
trans-unit.target: To add a new template-based deployment to the resource group, use the New-AzureResourceGroupDeployment command.

trans-unit.source: You can move existing resources to a new resource group.
trans-unit.target: You can move existing resources to a new resource group.

trans-unit.source: For examples, see <linkText>Move Resources to New Resource Group or Subscription</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For examples, see <linkText>Move Resources to New Resource Group or Subscription</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To delete a resource from the resource group, use the Remove-AzureResource cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To delete a resource from the resource group, use the Remove-AzureResource cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet deletes the resource, but does not delete the resource group.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet deletes the resource, but does not delete the resource group.

trans-unit.source: This command removes the TestSite2 website from the TestRG resource group.
trans-unit.target: This command removes the TestSite2 website from the TestRG resource group.

trans-unit.source: To delete a resource group, use the Remove-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To delete a resource group, use the Remove-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet deletes the resource group and its resources.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet deletes the resource group and its resources.

trans-unit.source: As you experiment with the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager modules, you are likely to encounter errors.
trans-unit.target: As you experiment with the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager modules, you are likely to encounter errors.

trans-unit.source: Use the tips in this section to resolve them.
trans-unit.target: Use the tips in this section to resolve them.

trans-unit.source: The AzureResourceManager module includes cmdlets that help you to prevent errors.
trans-unit.target: The AzureResourceManager module includes cmdlets that help you to prevent errors.

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureLocation: This cmdlet gets the locations that support each type of resource.
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureLocation: This cmdlet gets the locations that support each type of resource.

trans-unit.source: Before you enter a location for a resource, use this cmdlet to verify that the location supports the resource type.
trans-unit.target: Before you enter a location for a resource, use this cmdlet to verify that the location supports the resource type.

trans-unit.source: Test-AzureResourceGroupTemplate: Test your template and template parameter before you use them.
trans-unit.target: Test-AzureResourceGroupTemplate: Test your template and template parameter before you use them.

trans-unit.source: Enter a custom or gallery template and the template parameter values you plan to use.
trans-unit.target: Enter a custom or gallery template and the template parameter values you plan to use.

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet tests whether the template is internally consistent and whether your parameter value set matches the template.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet tests whether the template is internally consistent and whether your parameter value set matches the template.

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureResourceGroupLog: This cmdlet gets the entries in the log for each deployment of the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureResourceGroupLog: This cmdlet gets the entries in the log for each deployment of the resource group.

trans-unit.source: If something goes wrong, begin by examining the deployment logs.
trans-unit.target: If something goes wrong, begin by examining the deployment logs.

trans-unit.source: Verbose and Debug: The cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module call REST APIs that do the actual work.
trans-unit.target: Verbose and Debug: The cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module call REST APIs that do the actual work.

trans-unit.source: To see the messages that the APIs return, set the $DebugPreference variable to "Continue" and use the Verbose common parameter in your commands.
trans-unit.target: To see the messages that the APIs return, set the $DebugPreference variable to "Continue" and use the Verbose common parameter in your commands.

trans-unit.source: The messages often provide vital clues about the cause of any failures.
trans-unit.target: The messages often provide vital clues about the cause of any failures.

trans-unit.source: Your Azure credentials have not been set up or have expired: To refresh the credentials in your Windows PowerShell session, use the Add-AzureAccount cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure credentials have not been set up or have expired: To refresh the credentials in your Windows PowerShell session, use the Add-AzureAccount cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The credentials in a publish settings file are not sufficient for the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module.
trans-unit.target: The credentials in a publish settings file are not sufficient for the cmdlets in the AzureResourceManager module.

trans-unit.source: To learn about creating Resource Manager templates, see <linkText>Authoring Azure Resource Manager Templates</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn about creating Resource Manager templates, see <linkText>Authoring Azure Resource Manager Templates</linkText><title></title>.
